DOC.HEAD: Wednesday's Developments in Panama
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief summary of events Wednesday in Panama: _ Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega remained holed up in the Vatican embassy in Panama City. A Vatican spokesman said he did not see how Noriega could be turned over to the United States, which has no extradition treaty with Panama. _ President Bush said negotiations to bring Noriega to trial would continue. He appeared to leave open the possibility that Noriega could be tried in Panama instead of the United States. _ U.S. soldiers set up powerful loudspeakers outside the Vatican embassy, blaring music and radio news reports about negotiations over Noriega's status. _ The U.S. Justice Department asked France, Switzerland, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom to freeze bank accounts in which Noriega is believed to have stashed more than $10 million in ``illegal drug money.'' France froze accounts in two banks holding $3.3 million; Swiss officials placed a ``precautionary'' freeze on two accounts. _ The Panama Canal, closed during the U.S. invasion, was returning to normal gradually. Panama City residents returned to work and lined up outside grocery stores. _ Panama's election commission certified that the U.S.-installed president, Guillermo Endara, won the May 7 election that was nullified by Noriega.
